These channels, which are of key importance for control of insulin release, are a hetero-oligomeric complex of pore-forming Kir6.2 subunits and sulfonylurea receptor (SUR1) subunits with two nucleotide-binding domains (NBD1 and NBD2). We divided SUR1 into two halves at Pro-1042. Expression of either the individual N- or C-terminal domain in a baculovirus expression system did not lead to glibenclamide binding activity, although studies with green fluorescent protein fusion proteins showed that both half-molecules were inserted into the plasma membrane. However, significant glibenclamide binding activity was observed when the half-molecules were co-expressed (even when NBD2 was deleted from the C-terminal half-molecule). Simultaneous expression of Kir6.2 resulted in enhanced glibenclamide binding activity. We conclude that the glibenclamide-binding site includes amino acid residues from both halves of the molecule, that there is strong interaction between different regions of SUR1, that NBD2 is not essential for glibenclamide binding, and that interactions between Kir6.2 and SUR1 participate in ATP-sensitive potassium channel assembly. Investigation of NBD1-green fluorescent protein fusion protein distribution inside insect cells expressing C-terminal halves of SUR1 demonstrated strong interaction between NBD1 and NBD2. We also expressed and purified NBD1 from Escherichia coli. Purified NBD1 was found to exist as a tetramer indicating strong homomeric attractions and a possible role for NBD1 in SUR1 assembly. ATP-sensitive potassium ATP-binding cassette nucleotide-binding domain(s) sulfonylurea receptor transmembrane green fluorescent protein A central component of transmembrane signaling in the pancreatic β-cell is the ATP-sensitive potassium (KATP)1 channel that couples changes in plasma glucose concentration to insulin secretion and is also the target for the sulfonylurea drugs used to treat type I diabetes (1.Ashcroft S.J.H. Ashcroft F.M. Nunez J. Dumont J.E. Hormones and Cell Regulation No. 14. 198. Colloque INSERM/J. Libbey Eurotext Ltd., Paris1989: 99-103Google Scholar, 2.Ashcroft S.J.H. Niki I. Kenna S. Weng L. Skeer J. Coles B. Ashcroft F.M. Adv. Exp. Med. Biol. 1993; 334: 47-61Crossref PubMed Scopus (17) Google Scholar) and for diazoxide, which inhibits insulin secretion and is used to treat insulinoma and familial persistent hypoglycemia and hyperinsulinaemia of infants (3.Dunne M.J. Petersen O.H. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1991; 1071: 67-82Crossref PubMed Scopus (152) Google Scholar). Metabolic regulation of KATP channels in response to an elevation of blood glucose is mediated by an increased rate of metabolism of the sugar within the β-cell and a consequent increase in intracellular [ATP]/[ADP] ratio; ATP blocks the channels whereas MgADP activates them. Closure of KATP channels in response to sulfonylureas and opening of the channels by diazoxide involves direct binding of the drugs to the channel. The β-cell KATP channel contains two subunits, Kir6.2, an inwardly rectifying potassium channel, and SUR1, which contains the high affinity sulfonylurea-binding site and whose presence in the complex is essential for regulated channel activity (4.Aguilar-Bryan L. Nichols C.G. Wechsler S.W. Clement J.P. Boyd III, A.E. Gonzalez G. Herrera-Sosa H. Nguy K. Bryan J. Nelson D.A. Science. 1995; 268: 423-426Crossref PubMed Scopus (1281) Google Scholar, 5.Inagaki N. Gonoi T. Clement J.P. Namba N. Inazawa J. Gonzalez G. Aguilar-Bryan L. Seino S. Bryan J. Science. 1995; 270: 1166-1170Crossref PubMed Scopus (1610) Google Scholar). Channel closure is thought to be mediated by effects of ATP on Kir6.2 (6.Tucker S.J. Gribble F.M. Zhao C. Trapp S. Ashcroft F.M. Nature. 1997; 387: 179-183Crossref PubMed Scopus (675) Google Scholar) whereas SUR1 endows the KATP channel with sensitivity to the inhibitory effects of sulfonylureas and the stimulatory effects of MgADP and potassium channel openers (7.Nichols C. Shyng S.-L. Nestorowicz A. Glaser B. Clement J.P., IV Gonzalez G. Aguilar-Bryan L. Permutt M. Bryan J. Science. 1996; 272: 1785-1787Crossref PubMed Scopus (468) Google Scholar, 8.Gribble F.M. Tucker S.J. Ashcroft F.M. EMBO J. 1997; 16: 1145-1152Crossref PubMed Scopus (310) Google Scholar). Studies on fusion constructs with fixed SUR1:Kir6.2 ratios suggest that the native channel has a (SUR1∼Kir6.2)4 stoichiometry (9.Inagaki N. Gonoi T. Seino S. FEBS Lett. 1997; 409: 232-236Crossref PubMed Scopus (245) Google Scholar, 10.Clement J.P. Kunjilwar K. Gonzalez G. Schwanstecher M. Panten U. Aguilar-Bryan L. Bryan J. Neuron. 1997; 18: 827-838Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (622) Google Scholar). A topographical model for SUR1 based on hydrophobicity plots proposes that SUR1 contains two tandem repeats of six transmembrane helices, each set followed by a large cytosolic loop, plus an additional N-terminal hydrophobic region containing five transmembrane helices (11.Tusnady G.E. Bakos E. Varadi A. Sarkadi B. FEBS Lett. 1997; 402: 1-3Crossref PubMed Scopus (215) Google Scholar). SUR1 is classified as a member of the ATP-binding cassette (ABC) superfamily, and the two cytosolic loops, each containing a Walker A and Walker B motif (12.Walker J. Saraste M. Runswick M. Gah N. EMBO J. 1982; 1: 945-951Crossref PubMed Scopus (4234) Google Scholar), are suggested to function as nucleotide-binding domains (NBDs). Disruption of either NBD results in the unregulated insulin secretion found in hypoglycemia and hyperinsulinaemia of infants (13.Thomas P.M. Cote G.J. Wohllk N. Haddad B. Mathew P.M. Rabl W. Aguilar-Bryan L. Gagel R.F. Bryan J. Science. 1995; 268: 426-429Crossref PubMed Scopus (743) Google Scholar, 14.Thomas P.M. Wohllk N. Huang E. Kuhnle U. Rabl W. Gagel R.F. Cote G.J. Am. J. Hum. Genet. 1996; 59: 510-518PubMed Google Scholar). Only limited information is available on the regions of SUR1 and Kir6.2 important for channel assembly and ligand binding. Photoaffinity labeling of both SUR1 and Kir6.2 by radioactive sulfonylurea provided evidence for close association between the two channel subunits (10.Clement J.P. Kunjilwar K. Gonzalez G. Schwanstecher M. Panten U. Aguilar-Bryan L. Bryan J. Neuron. 1997; 18: 827-838Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (622) Google Scholar), and a direct physical association was demonstrated by immunoprecipitation (15.Lorenz E. Alekseev A.E. Krapivinsky G.B. Carrasco A.J. Clapham D.E. Terzic A. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1998; 18: 1652-1659Crossref PubMed Scopus (79) Google Scholar). The proximal C terminus of Kir6.2 has been shown to be important for interaction with SUR1 (16.Giblin J.P. Leaney J.L. Tinker A. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 22652-22659Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (56) Google Scholar). Such an association has been suggested to facilitate insertion of channel-containing vesicles into the plasma membrane or to stabilize channels once inserted into the plasma membrane (17.Makhina E.N. Nichols C.G. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 3369-3374Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (46) Google Scholar). There is evidence that both N and C termini of Kir6.2 cooperate to form the ATP-binding site (18.Tucker S.J. Gribble F.M. Proks P. Trapp S. Ryder T.J. Haug T. Reimann F. Ashcroft F.M. EMBO J. 1998; 17: 3290-3296Crossref PubMed Scopus (198) Google Scholar). Studies on SUR1-SUR2A chimeras have shown that the C-terminal set of transmembrane domains of SUR1 is implicated in binding of sulfonylureas (19.Ashfield R. Gribble F.M. Ashcroft S.J.H. Ashcroft F.M. Diabetes. 1999; 48: 1341-1347Crossref PubMed Scopus (165) Google Scholar) and that the first five transmembrane (TM) domains and the C terminus specify the spontaneous bursting pattern and sensitivity to inhibition by ATP, respectively (20.Babenko A.P. Gonzalez G. Bryan J. Biochem. Biophys. Res. Commun. 1999; 255: 231-238Crossref PubMed Scopus (67) Google Scholar). We have previously shown that functional KATP channels can be expressed in insect cells using baculovirus (21.Mikhailov M.V. Proks P. Ashcroft F.M. Ashcroft S.J.H. FEBS Lett. 1998; 429: 390-394Crossref PubMed Scopus (36) Google Scholar). In the present study we have used the baculovirus system to express, both independently and in combination, the N- and C-proximal halves of SUR1, containing NBD1 and NBD2, respectively. We showed that neither half-molecule alone gave rise to detectable glibenclamide binding activity although using green fluorescent protein (GFP)-tagged constructs we were able to show that both half-molecules were targeted to the plasma membrane. Co-expression of both half-molecules, however, resulted in the appearance of significant glibenclamide binding activity, which was further increased by the simultaneous expression of Kir6.2. Deletion of the second NBD from the C-proximal half did not prevent assembly of the two halves to form a glibenclamide-binding site. These data indicate that there are strong interactions between two different regions of SUR1 that make possible self-association. Using GFP-tagged NBD1 we were able to provide evidence that such interactions occur between NBD1 and NBD2. We also demonstrated that NBD1 forms a tetramer, suggesting that homomeric interactions of this domain may be important in channel assembly. Sf9 (Spodoptera frugiperda) cells were propagated at 28 °C in TC100 medium containing 10% fetal calf serum. Cells were infected by each recombinant baculovirus at a multiplicity of infection of 10, and expressed products were analyzed 2 days after infection. For virus stocks, Sf9 cells were infected by each recombinant baculovirus at a multiplicity of infection of 0.1, and the supernatant was collected 5 days later. Penta-His antibody (QIAGEN) was used in Western blots for analysis of recombinant protein expression. We constructed transfer vectors containing DNA fragments encoding rat SUR1 (4.Aguilar-Bryan L. Nichols C.G. Wechsler S.W. Clement J.P. Boyd III, A.E. Gonzalez G. Herrera-Sosa H. Nguy K. Bryan J. Nelson D.A. Science. 1995; 268: 423-426Crossref PubMed Scopus (1281) Google Scholar) and mouse Kir6.2 (22.Sakura H. Ämmälä C. Smith P.A. Gribble F.M. Ashcroft F.M. FEBS Lett. 1995; 377: 338-344Crossref PubMed Scopus (402) Google Scholar) under control of the polyhedron promoter in the pAcYM1 vector. We designed a transfer vector for expression of the N-terminal half of SUR1 (pAcCas1) containing a SUR1 sequence (amino acids 1–55), an adapter containingBamHI and NotI sites, and sequences encoding a C-terminal His6 tag. The GFP gene (23.Prasher D.C. Eckenrode V.K. Ward W.W. Prendergast F.G. Cormier M.J. Gene. 1992; 111: 229-233Crossref PubMed Scopus (1755) Google Scholar) was inserted at theNotI site (by NotI–EagI) to create pAcCas1G to obtain a GFP fusion protein. pAcNSUR1 and pAcNSUR1G transfer vectors were obtained by cloning a polymerase chain reaction copy of the SUR1 amino acid 55–1042 sequence in pAcCas1 and pAcCas1G, respectively. For cloning of the C-terminal part of SUR1 we constructed a transfer vector (pAcCas2) containing a SUR1 leader sequence (amino acids 1–27), NotI restriction sites for cloning, and a C-terminal His6 tag. The GFP gene was also incorporated in this vector to give pACas2G so that GFP fusion proteins were obtained. A polymerase chain reaction product coding for amino acids 1042–1580 of SUR1 was cloned in both vectors to obtain pAcCSUR1 and pAcCSUR1G transfer vectors. A truncated version of the C-terminal part of SUR1 without NBD2 (amino acids 1042–1299) was cloned in pAcCas2 to obtain pAcCSUR1tr transfer vector. NBD1 (amino acids 616–982) and NBD2 (amino acids 1317–1580) were cloned in the BamHI site of pAcYM1 byBglII digestion from a polymerase chain reaction product providing a C-terminal His6 tag and an additionalBamHI site for cloning. The GFP gene was inserted in that site to obtain pAcNBD1G and pAcNBD2G transfer vectors. Transfer vectors were used for co-transfection of Sf9 cells together withAutographa californica nuclear polyhedrosis virus (AcNPV PAK6) (24.King L. Possee R.D. The Baculovirus Expression System: A Laboratory Guide. Chapman & Hall, London1992Crossref Google Scholar). Recombinant baculoviruses AcNPVNSUR1, AcNPVNSUR1G, AcNPVCSUR2, AcNPVCSUR1, AcNPVCSUR1tr, AcNPVNBD1G, and AcNPVNBD2G were obtained by using the corresponding transfer vectors, plaque purified three times, and used for infection of Sf9 cells. The same fragment of NBD1 was inserted in the BamHI site of pET24d (Novagen) to obtain expression of His-tagged NBD1 in Escherichia coli. Sf9 cells resuspended at a density of 2 × 106 cells/ml in TC100 were incubated at room temperature for 90 min with [3H]glibenclamide (10 nm) and test substances in a final volume of 400 μl. The incubation was stopped by rapid separation on Whatman GF/C filters previously soaked in TC100 for 30 min. Filters were washed, and specific binding was determined as described previously (25.Niki I. Kelly R.P. Ashcroft S.J.H. Ashcroft F.M. Pfluegers Arch. Eur. J. Physiol. 1989; 415: 47-55Crossref PubMed Scopus (65) Google Scholar). His-tagged NBD1 was expressed inE. coli according to the Novagen manual. Cells were disrupted by ultrasonication, and cleared lysate was used for nickel affinity chromatography (Ni-NTA agarose, QIAGEN) according to the supplier's manual. After elution from Ni-NTA agarose with 200 mm imidazole in buffer A (50 mm Tris-HCl, pH 8.8, 100 mm NaCl, 1 mm β-mercaptoethanol) the solution was changed to buffer A using a PD10 column (Amersham Pharmacia Biotech). Gel filtration on a HiLoad 16/60, Superdex 200 pg column (Amersham Pharmacia Biotech) was used to obtain highly purified protein. Protein concentration was measured by UV adsorption (predicted absorption of 0.1% NBD1 at 278 nm is 0.812 mg−1cm−1) on a U2010 spectrophotometer (Hitachi). Analytical ultracentrifugation was used to characterize the oligomerization of NBD1. 0.5 ml of purified NBD1 (1 mg/ml) was loaded on a linear 5–30% sucrose gradient in buffer A and centrifuged (20,000 rpm for 16 h) using a TST 41.14 rotor in a Centricon T-1055 ultracentrifuge. 1-ml fractions were collected, and protein concentration was measured by UV adsorption. Bovine serum albumin (M r 66,000), β-galactosidase (M r 116,000), and urease (M r 272,000) were centrifuged under the same condition and used for calibration. GFP-expressing insect cells were grown on coverslips and viewed with a LEITZ DMIRB fluorescent microscope (Leica Microscopie und Systeme GmbH). Ionvision III software was used for analyzing images. Fig.1 illustrates the predicted topology of SUR1 and the regions of SUR1 expressed by vectors used in this study. The N-proximal half-molecule, designated NSUR1, contained the first two sets of putative TM domains, NBD1 and the first TM helix of the second 6-TM set. A variant of this construct, designated NSUR1G, had a C-terminal GFP tag. The C-proximal half-molecule, designated CSUR1, contained the last five putative TM helices and NBD2 and had an artificial leader sequence to facilitate membrane insertion. The leader sequence was identical to that of SUR1 itself. A truncated variant, CSUR1tr, lacked NBD2. An N-terminal GFP tag and leader sequence were added to CSUR1 to produce CSUR1G. We also prepared the two nucleotide-binding domains, NBD1 and NBD2, with C-terminal GFP tags (NBD1G and NBDG). All recombinant proteins were designed to contain a His6 tag. Fig. 2 shows Western blots (using Penta-His antibody) of Sf9 insect cells expressing the recombinant proteins. The positions of the main bands on the Western blot correspond to those predicted from amino acid sequences.Figure 2Western blot of lysed Sf9 insect cells expressing SUR1 and SUR1 fragments with anti-His6antisera. Lane 1, SUR1; lane 2, NBD1;lane 3, NBD1G; lane 4, NBD2; lane 5, NBD2G; lane 6, NSUR1; lane 7, NSUR1G; lane 8, CSUR1; lane 9, CSUR1G; lane 10, CSUR1tr.View Large Image Figure ViewerDownload Hi-res image Download (PPT) GFP was used as marker for investigation of recombinant protein localization. Fluorescence microscopy of Sf9 cells expressing recombinant proteins is shown in Fig. 3. GFP itself (Fig. 3 A) was randomly distributed inside the insect cell and did not bind to the plasma membrane. Fig. 3 Bshows that NBD1G was also randomly distributed inside the insect cell. In contrast to NBD1G, NBD2G forms inclusion bodies (Fig.3 C). Fig. 3, D and E show that the N- and C-terminal halves of SUR1 tagged with GFP were both expressed at the plasma membrane of Sf9 insect cells infected with the corresponding recombinant baculovirus. These data show that individual regions of SUR1 possess plasma membrane insertion abilities. NBD1 expressed in Sf9 cells as a GFP fusion protein was distributed throughout the cell (Fig. 3 B). After co-expression of NBD1G and the C-terminal half-molecule CSUR1, NBD1G was found mostly near the plasma membrane (Fig. 3 F). This effect disappeared after deletion of NBD2 from the C-terminal part of SUR1, i.e. when NBD1G was co-expressed with CSUR1tr (Fig. 3 G). These data indicate strong interaction between NBD1 and NBD2. Co-expression of NBD1G with Kir6.2 did not localize NBD1G to the plasma membrane (Fig.3 H) suggesting a lack of strong interactions between Kir6.2 and NBD1. As we have previously demonstrated (21.Mikhailov M.V. Proks P. Ashcroft F.M. Ashcroft S.J.H. FEBS Lett. 1998; 429: 390-394Crossref PubMed Scopus (36) Google Scholar), Sf9 cells infected with SUR1 express glibenclamide binding activity (Fig. 4). The specific binding activity at 10 nm [3H]glibenclamide amounted to approximately 2.5 × 106 binding sites per cell, more than 1000-fold greater than the density of sulfonylurea-binding sites in pancreatic β-cells. When Sf9 cells expressed either the N-terminal SUR1 half-molecule, NSUR1, or the C-terminal half-molecule, CSUR1, glibenclamide binding was not significantly greater than in cells infected with the parent baculovirus. However, in cells co-infected with both NSUR1 and CSUR1 a substantial increase of glibenclamide binding activity was demonstrated. There was no significant decrease in observed glibenclamide binding activity in cells co-infected with NSUR1 and CSUR1tr indicating that NBD2 is not essential for assembly of SUR1 and formation of the glibenclamide-binding site(s). Co-expression of Kir6.2 with NSUR1 and CSUR1 (as well as with NSUR1 and CSUR1tr) increased the density of glibenclamide-binding sites suggesting that Kir6.2 facilitates SUR1 assembly. The studies described above using GFP-tagged NBD1 showed that NBD1 can take part in KATP channel assembly. We found that the expression level of NBD1 in insect cells using the baculovirus expression system was too low for large scale NBD1 purification. Therefore we cloned NBD1 inE. coli as a His-tagged protein. A high expression level of NBD1 was observed, and after purification by nickel affinity chromatography and gel filtration we obtained highly purified NBD1 protein, as illustrated in Fig.5 A. From gel filtration under non-denaturing conditions, we found that the purified NBD1 exists primarily in an oligomeric form (Fig. 5 B). To verify the exact number of molecules in the complex we carried out analytical ultracentrifugation in a sucrose gradient of the protein obtained from the main peak. As shown in Fig. 5 C, the mobility of NBD1 corresponds to a M r of 167,000. Because the predicted M r of NBD1 is 41,000 we conclude that under non-denaturing conditions NBD1 exists as a tetramer. Many ABC transporters contain four structural domains that include two sets of TM regions and two cytosolic NBDs (26.Higgins C.F. Cell. 1995; 82: 693-696Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (340) Google Scholar). In prokaryotic ABC transporters the TM and NBD regions are often separate polypeptides. Moreover some ABC proteins contain only a single set of six TM helices and one NBD. It has been suggested, therefore, that many members of the ABC superfamily have evolved by duplication or fusion of previously autonomous half-molecules (27.Higgins C.F. Annu. Rev. Cell Biol. 1992; 8: 67-113Crossref PubMed Scopus (3350) Google Scholar). P-glycoprotein consists of two homologous halves, each composed of 6 putative TM helices and an NBD. Either half-molecule, when expressed in Sf9 cells, exhibited ATPase activity that was not stimulated by drugs (28.Loo T.W. Clarke D.M. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 7750-7755Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). However, drug stimulation of ATPase activity was present following co-expression of both halves of P-glycoprotein, indicating the ability of the two fragments to associate and couple ATPase activity to drug binding. The predicted topology of SUR1 and other ABC transporters such as the multidrug resistance protein is not consistent with such a symmetrical arrangement because of the large additional N-terminal extension containing several additional TM segments. Nevertheless when the multidrug resistance protein was divided into two, each half-molecule expressed in Sf9 cells was able to integrate into the plasma membrane and associate to form a functional transporter (29.Gao M. Loe D.W. Grant C.E. Cole S.P.C. Deeley R.G. J. Biol. Chem. 1996; 271: 27782-27787Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (77) Google Scholar). We have now applied such a complementation approach to SUR1. We divided SUR1 at position Pro-1042 into two halves. These N- and C-terminal half-molecules were expressed separately and together in Sf9 cells using a baculovirus system that we have previously applied to the expression of active KATP channels (21.Mikhailov M.V. Proks P. Ashcroft F.M. Ashcroft S.J.H. FEBS Lett. 1998; 429: 390-394Crossref PubMed Scopus (36) Google Scholar). Both half-molecules, when expressed in Sf9 cells as GFP-tagged proteins, were concentrated at the plasma membrane. However, glibenclamide binding activity could not be detected in cells expressing either half-molecule. When the two half-molecules were co-expressed, however, substantial glibenclamide binding activity was found. These data indicate that the two halves of SUR1 interact and that the glibenclamide-binding site requires residues from both halves of the molecule. This latter conclusion is consistent with the findings from a study of chimeric SURs, which concluded that glibenclamide interacts with two high affinity sites on SUR1 (19.Ashfield R. Gribble F.M. Ashcroft S.J.H. Ashcroft F.M. Diabetes. 1999; 48: 1341-1347Crossref PubMed Scopus (165) Google Scholar). We can exclude NBD2 from a significant contribution to the glibenclamide-binding site(s), because co-expression of NSUR1 with the truncated C-terminal half-molecule lacking NBD2 also resulted in expression of glibenclamide binding activity. This suggests interaction between the TM domains of the C-terminal half of SUR1 with either cytosolic or TM domains in the N-terminal half-molecule. The increased glibenclamide binding observed when Kir6.2 was co-expressed with NSUR1 and CSUR1 or CSUR1tr is indicative of interaction between SUR1 half-molecules and Kir6.2 to facilitate SUR1 assembly. There is evidence that the C-terminal region of Kir6.2 may be important in this interaction (16.Giblin J.P. Leaney J.L. Tinker A. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 22652-22659Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (56) Google Scholar). The density of glibenclamide-binding sites in cells co-expressing the two half-molecules was approximately 25% of that in cells expressing full-length SUR1. This may indicate that the binding activity of the reconstituted protein is less than that of the intact molecule. However, it is more likely to be attributable to heterogeneity of the infected cell population. We cannot determine the stoichiometry with which the half-molecules are expressed in individual cells; therefore the lower glibenclamide binding may reflect the proportion of half-molecules able to heterodimerize. NBD1 is the major cytosolic domain in NSUR1. It therefore seemed possible that NBD1 interacted with CSUR1 to facilitate formation of functional SUR1. The GFP fusion protein NBD1G was used to test this possibility. NBD1G was distributed throughout the cell when expressed alone. However, when co-expressed with CSUR1 there was significant localization of NBD1G to the plasma membrane. Because this localization was not observed in cells co-expressing CSUR1tr we conclude that there is also interaction between NBD1 and NBD2 in assembly of SUR1. In cells co-expressing Kir6.2 and NBD1G there was no detectable membrane localization of NBD1G, suggesting that NBD1 does not strongly interact with Kir6.2. When purified NBD1 was studied in vitro this protein domain was found to exist as a tetramer. Because four SUR1 molecules are believed to be present in the active KATP channel this observation suggests that homomeric NBD1 interactions may play a key role in channel assembly. The complementation approach described here has been applied to several membrane proteins. For example, when C- and N-terminal halves of the GLUT1 glucose transporter were co-expressed in Sf9 cells, a ligand-binding site was formed (30.Cope D.L. Holman G.D. Baldwin S.A. Wolstenholme A.J. Biochem. J. 1994; 300: 291-294Crossref PubMed Scopus (36) Google Scholar). Fragments of the human red cell anion exchanger (band 3; AE1) that individually were not competent for transport, were able to assemble to form a functional anion transporter when co-expressed in Xenopus oocytes (31.Groves J.D. Tanner M.J.A. J. Biol. Chem. 1995; 270: 9097-9105Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (66) Google Scholar, 32.Wang L. Groves J.D. Mawby W.J. Tanner M.J. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 10631-10638Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (36) Google Scholar). Functionally active β3-adrenergic (33.Kobilka B.K. Kobilka T.S. Daniel K. Regan J.W. Caron M.G. Lefkowitz R.J. Science. 1988; 240: 1310-1316Crossref PubMed Scopus (606) Google Scholar) and muscarinic cholinergic (34.Maggio R. Vogel Z. Wess J. FEBS Lett. 1993; 319: 195-200Crossref PubMed Scopus (118) Google Scholar) receptors have also been reconstituted from co-expressed N- and C-terminal domains. These studies have been interpreted in terms of a two-stage model for the process whereby polytopic integral membrane proteins attain their folded structure within the membrane (35.Popot J.L. Engelman D.M. Biochemistry. 1990; 29: 4031-4037Crossref PubMed Scopus (820) Google Scholar). According to this hypothesis, transmembrane α-helixes fold independently on insertion into the membrane where they are stabilized by main chain hydrogen bonds and hydrophobic interactions with the lipid bilayer. Subsequently these independent α-helical domains associate to form the final structure without significant secondary structure rearrangement. Our results with SUR1 are consistent with such a model.

S-modulin in frog or its bovine homologue, recoverin, is a 23-kDa EF-hand Ca2+-binding protein found in rod photoreceptors. The Ca2+-bound form of S-modulin binds to rhodopsin kinase (Rk) and inhibits its activity. Through this regulation, S-modulin is thought to modulate the light sensitivity of a rod. In the present study, we tried to identify the interaction site of the Ca2+-bound form of S-modulin to Rk. First, we mapped roughly the interaction regions by using partial peptides of S-modulin. The result suggested that a specific region near the amino terminus is the interaction site of S-modulin. We then identified the essential amino acid residues in this region by using S-modulin mutant proteins: four amino acid residues (Phe22, Glu26, Phe55, and Thr92) were suggested to interact with Rk. These residues are located in a small closed pocket in the Ca2+-free, inactive form of S-modulin, but exposed to the surface of the molecule in the Ca2+-bound, active form of S-modulin. Two additional amino acid residues (Tyr108 and Arg150) were found to be crucial for the Ca2+-dependent conformational changes of S-modulin. In the present study, we tried to identify the amino acid residues in S-modulin responsible for the interaction with Rk. For this purpose, first we mapped roughly the regions necessary for the interaction by using S-modulin partial peptides, and based on the result obtained, we expressed S-modulin mutant proteins to identify the amino acid residues responsible for the interaction. Site-directed mutagenesis was done according to the method of Matsuda et al. (21.Matsuda S. Hisatomi O. Ishino T. Kobayashi Y. Tokunaga F. J. Boil. Chem. 1998; 273: 20223-20227Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (21) Google Scholar) with some modification. We used following oligonucleotides and their complementary oligonucleotides as primers for site-directed mutagenesis: 5′-GGAGGAGGCGCAGCTGAACACC-3′ for L16A, 5′-GCAGCTGAACGCCAAATTTACCCAGG-3′ for T20A, 5′-CTGAACACCAAAGCTACCCAGGAGG-3′ for F22A, 5′-CCCAGGAGGCACTGTGCACCTGGTAC-3′ for E26A, 5′-GAACTGTGCACCGCGTACCAGTCTTTC-3′ for W30A, 5′-GCATTTACTCCAAGGCCTTTCCAGAC-3′ for F55A, 5′-CTCCAAGTTCGCTCCAGACGCTG-3′ for F56A, 5′-GGAATACATGATAGCGGCACATATGACC-3′ for L89A, 5′-CGCTACATATGGCCTCATCTGGCAAAG-3′ for T92A, 5′-CCTCATCTGGCGCAGCCAACCAGAAAC-3′ for K96A, 5′-GCCAACCAGGCACTGGAGTGGG-3′ for K100A, 5′-GCCTTCTGTTTAGCCGATGTGGATGG-3′ for Y108A, 5′-CAGAGAAGGCGACAAATAAAATATGGGTCTAC-3′ for R150A, 5′-CAGAGAAGAGGACAAATAAAGCATGGGTCTAC-3′ for I154A, and 5′-CAAGAACAAAGAAGCTTTGCGTCTAATCC-3′ for I181A. A DNA fragment encoding each mutant was inserted between the NcoI andXhoI site of a pET-16b (Novagen) plasmid vector. The sequence of the insert was checked before transfection toEscherichia coli (BL21DE3) by using ABI PRISM 310 genetic analyzer (Perkin-Elmer). The cell was co-transfected with pBB131, an expression vector of N-myristoyltransferase, kindly provided by Prof. Jeffrey I. Gordon (22.Duronio R.J. Jackson-Machelski E. Heuckeroth R.O. Olins P.O. Devine C.S. Yonemoto W. Slice L.W. Taylor S.S. Gordon J.I. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1990; 87: 1506-1510Crossref PubMed Scopus (200) Google Scholar). Myristoylated S-modulin and its mutant proteins were expressed according to the method of Hisatomi et al. (23.Hisatomi O. Ishino T. Matsuda S. Yamaguchi K. Kobayashi Y. Kawamura S. Tokunaga F. Biochem. Biophys. Res. Commun. 1997; 234: 173-177Crossref PubMed Scopus (9) Google Scholar). Expressed proteins were purified according to the method of Sato and Kawamura (19.Sato N. Kawamura S. J. Biochem. (Tokyo). 1997; 122: 1139-1145Crossref PubMed Scopus (15) Google Scholar). After the purification, each protein was concentrated and the buffer solution was replaced with a potassium-gluconate buffer (K-gluconate buffer: 115 mm potassium-gluconate, 2.5 mm KCl, 2 mm MgCl2, 1 mm dithiothreitol, 0.1 mm CaCl2, 0.2 mm EGTA, 10 mm HEPES, pH 7.5). The purified fractions contained >98% of S-modulin or its mutant judging from the Coomassie Brilliant Blue staining after SDS-polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis, and >95% S-modulin was myristoylated judging from our reversed-phase column chromatography. The sample was frozen in liquid nitrogen and stored at −80 °C until use. Peptides were designed as described under “Results and Discussion,” and purchased from Sawady Technology, Tokyo. The purity of a peptide was >93%. ROS membranes of a frog (Rana catesbeiana) were isolated as described previously (19.Sato N. Kawamura S. J. Biochem. (Tokyo). 1997; 122: 1139-1145Crossref PubMed Scopus (15) Google Scholar) with some modification. Briefly, ROSs were brushed off the retinas into the K-gluconate buffer and fragmented. Then, ROS membranes were washed twice with the K-gluconate buffer and stored overnight at 4 °C in the same buffer supplemented with 0.5 mm EGTA to eliminate endogenous S-modulin. The next day, the membranes were washed twice with the K-gluconate buffer and suspended in the same buffer so that the concentration of rhodopsin was 50 μm. The sample was aliquoted and stored at −20 °C until use. All of these procedures were done in complete darkness with the aid of an infrared image converter (NVR 2015, NEC). S-modulin, its mutant or a partial peptide of S-modulin was mixed with ROS membranes in complete darkness. The free Ca2+ concentration in the mixture was adjusted by adding the K-gluconate buffer supplemented with 5 mmCaCl2 or 10 mm EGTA. Then, the mixture was placed on ice and irradiated with a 100-watt tungsten-halogen lamp for 1 min (∼100% bleach), and incubated at room temperature for 9 min so that the reactions in the mixture were quasi-equilibrated. The phosphorylation reaction was started by mixing 15 μl of the mixture with 10 μl of the K-gluconate buffer containing 0.25 mm[γ-32P]ATP (24 MBq/μmol) and 1.25 mm GTP. The resultant reaction mixture contained 10 μm rhodopsin, 5 μm expressed protein or 2 mm peptide, 0.1 mm ATP, and 0.5 mm GTP. The concentration of the peptides (2 mm) was decided by measuring the dose-effect relation and it was a saturating concentration of the effective peptides. In a measurement using a peptide, 0.002% (w/v) Tween 80 was always added to the sample, because some of the peptides were not freely soluble. The addition of this detergent caused a negligible effect on rhodopsin phosphorylation: 5 ∼ 10% decrease of the phosphorylation was observed in a control experiment using S-modulin. After 2 min of incubation at room temperature, the reaction was terminated by adding 150 μl of 10% trichloroacetic acid. After centrifugation (10,000 × g, 5 min), the precipitate was washed with 500 μl of the K-gluconate buffer and subjected to SDS-polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis. The amount of32P incorporated into rhodopsin was quantified by using an image analyzer (BAS 2000, Fuji Film). Ca2+ binding assay was done according to the method of Matsuda et al.(21.Matsuda S. Hisatomi O. Ishino T. Kobayashi Y. Tokunaga F. J. Boil. Chem. 1998; 273: 20223-20227Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (21) Google Scholar) with some modification. Briefly, 0.2–0.4 ml of S-modulin or its mutant protein solution was dialyzed against a ∼100 times excess volume of buffer A (25 mm Tris-HCl, pH 8.0) for 3 h × 6 times to remove EGTA and Ca2+. Then each protein solution (20 μm protein) was mixed with an equal volume of buffer A supplemented with 0.2 mm45CaCl2(21.5 kBq/ml) in a Microcon-10 concentrator (Amicon). The membrane of the concentrator had been extensively washed by Milli-Q water. Then the sample was centrifuged and the pass-through was collected, and 15 μl of it was blotted on a laminated paper (Advantec MFS). As a control, 0.2 mm45CaCl2 solution (21.5 kBq/ml) mixed with an equal volume of buffer A was also blotted. The paper was dried, and the 45Ca activity was quantified by using an image analyzer (BAS 2000, Fuji Film). The quantity of Ca2+ bound to the protein was calculated from the difference between the 45Ca activity of the pass-through and that of the control. An expressed protein in the K-gluconate buffer (100 μm protein, 20 μl) was diluted with 180 μl of buffer B (20 mm KCl, 10 mm HEPES, 1 mm dithiothreitol, pH 7.5) supplemented with 233 μm CaCl2 or 1 mm EGTA, and loaded to an optical cell of 1-mm light path. Circular dichroism (CD) spectra were recorded on a Jasco 720W recording spectrophotometer. All scans were recorded at a bandwidth of 1 nm, scan speed of 10 nm/min, response time of 8 s, and at 20 ± 0.1 °C. CD spectrum of each sample was measured 6 times and averaged. First, we tried to map roughly the region(s) necessary for the inhibition of Rk by using partial peptides of S-modulin. The entire amino acid sequence of S-modulin was divided into 11 portions (Fig. 1), and a peptide corresponding to each portion was synthesized. We determined the length of a peptide so that each peptide consisted of ∼20 amino acid residues as well as α-helices in the Ca2+-bound form of bovine S-modulin (recoverin; Ref. 24.Ames J.B. Isima R. Tanaka T. Gordon J.I. Stryer L. Ikura M. Nature. 1997; 389: 198-202Crossref PubMed Scopus (428) Google Scholar) were almost intact. Rat/chicken VILIP1, one of the S-modulin family protein, lacks 10 amino acid residues at the COOH terminus (Val192-His201), but yet it does inhibit Rk as S-modulin does (25.De Castro E. Nef S. Fiumelli H. Lenz S.E. Kawamura S. Nef P. Biochem. Biophys. Res. Commun. 1995; 216: 133-140Crossref PubMed Scopus (77) Google Scholar). This fact indicates that this portion does not participate in the interaction with Rk. For this reason we eliminated this portion in the following study. On each peptide, we examined whether it inhibits rhodopsin phosphorylation by itself (Fig. 2). If such a peptide is present, this peptide probably appears on the surface of the Ca2+-bound form of S-modulin to interact with Rk. Fig. 2 summarizes the effects of the synthesized peptides on rhodopsin phosphorylation. Without S-modulin (Fig. 2, no S-mod), rhodopsin was phosphorylated independently on the Ca2+concentration, while with S-modulin present (Fig. 2, S-mod), rhodopsin phosphorylation was inhibited at a high Ca2+concentration (200 μm, filled bar). Namely, at high Ca2+ concentrations, S-modulin binds Ca2+and the Ca2+-bound form of S-modulin binds to RK to inhibit its activity. As can be seen in the figure, peptides 2, 5, 6, and 9 inhibited the phosphorylation independently on the Ca2+concentration and the other peptides did not show pronounced effects on the phosphorylation. These results suggested that the regions corresponding to peptides 2, 5, 6, and 9 are the site for the interaction with Rk. The half-effective peptide concentrations were ∼0.5 mm (peptide 2) and <0.25 mm (peptides 5, 6, and 9). At a saturating concentration (2 mm), peptides 5, 6, and 9 were almost as effective as the wild-type S-modulin but the effect of the peptide 2 did not seem to be complete (Fig. 2). Fig. 3 illustrates the localization of peptides 2, 5, 6, and 9 in a three-dimensional structure of the Ca2+-free form (A; Ref. 26.Tanaka T. Ames J.B. Harvey T.S. Stryer L. Ikura M. Nature. 1995; 376: 444-447Crossref PubMed Scopus (285) Google Scholar) and the Ca2+-bound form (B; Ref. 24.Ames J.B. Isima R. Tanaka T. Gordon J.I. Stryer L. Ikura M. Nature. 1997; 389: 198-202Crossref PubMed Scopus (428) Google Scholar) of bovine S-modulin. As can be seen in the figure, the localization of the four peptides does not seem to be well organized in the Ca2+-free form, but in the Ca2+-bound form, three of the peptides (peptides 2, 5, and 6) come close to each other and form a cluster. Because these peptides by themselves have the ability to inhibit rhodopsin phosphorylation (Fig. 2), it is likely that this is a region of S-modulin to interact with Rk. Although peptide 9 inhibited rhodopsin phosphorylation as the other three did, this peptide seems to be different from the others. Peptide 9 does not participate in the formation of the cluster in the Ca2+-bound form (see below). In the next step, we tried to identify the amino acid residues responsible for the interaction with Rk by using S-modulin mutant proteins. First, we decided amino acid residues to be mutated based on the criteria shown below, and then obtained expressed mutant proteins in which alanine substituted one of these amino acid residues. Then, we measured the effect of each mutant on rhodopsin phosphorylation. We decided the amino acid residues to be mutated based on the following criteria. Amino acid residues that are: 1) highly conserved among eight S-modulin homologues which are known to have the S-modulin activity (25.De Castro E. Nef S. Fiumelli H. Lenz S.E. Kawamura S. Nef P. Biochem. Biophys. Res. Commun. 1995; 216: 133-140Crossref PubMed Scopus (77) Google Scholar, 27.Kawamura S. Neurosci. Res. 1994; 20: 293-298Crossref PubMed Scopus (22) Google Scholar, 28.Kawamura S. Kuwata O. Yamada M. Matsuda S. Hisatomi O. Tokunaga F. J. Biol. Chem. 1996; 271: 21359-21364Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (37) Google Scholar); 2) located in or near the regions corresponding to peptides 2, 5, 6, or 9 and on the surface in the three-dimensional structure of the Ca2+-bound form of bovine S-modulin (24.Ames J.B. Isima R. Tanaka T. Gordon J.I. Stryer L. Ikura M. Nature. 1997; 389: 198-202Crossref PubMed Scopus (428) Google Scholar); 3) not present in the EF-hand structure (to exclude the possibility of the loss of the Ca2+-binding site); 4) not glycine or proline (to avoid the effect of the mutation on the structure of the peptide backbone). Fig. 4 shows the amino acid sequences of peptides 2, 5, 6, and 9 in the eight S-modulin homologues which are known to have the S-modulin activity. Based on the above criteria, we selected 11 amino acid residues (Fig. 4, boxed residues). In addition, Leu16, Phe55, Phe56, and Ile181 were selected: they are conserved among the eight S-modulin homologues and are located near peptides 2, 5, 6, and 9 in the three-dimensional structure of the Ca2+-bound form of bovine S-modulin. Thus, we obtained a total of 15 S-modulin mutants and examined the effect of each mutant on rhodopsin phosphorylation. Fig. 5 summarizes the effects of S-modulin and its mutants on rhodopsin phosphorylation. At a saturating Ca2+ concentration (100 μm, filled bars), rhodopsin phosphorylation was inhibited by addition of S-modulin or its mutants, but the inhibitory effect of each mutant protein was dependent on the mutation. Some of the mutants inhibited the phosphorylation as efficiently as wild-type S-modulin (L16A, W30A, L89A, K96A, I154A, and I181A). The other nine mutants (indicated byasterisks) caused weaker inhibition than wild-type S-modulin. The results indicated that these mutants partially lost the S-modulin activity and that the substituted amino acid residues in these mutants were necessary for S-modulin activity. Therefore, these nine residues were the candidates of the interaction sites. Among the nine effective amino acids (asterisks in Fig. 5), seven of them are present in peptides 2 (Thr20, Phe22, and Glu26), 5 (Thr92), 6 (Lys100and Tyr108), or 9 (Arg150), and two additional amino acid residues (Phe55 and Phe56) are present near the cluster formed in the Ca2+-bound form of S-modulin (see below). There are many possible mechanisms that account for the loss of the S-modulin activity in a given mutant. We thought the following possibilities: 1) total or a partial loss of the Ca2+binding; 2) inability to change the molecular conformation to the active form of S-modulin; 3) mutation of amino acid residues responsible for the interaction with Rk. To identify the amino acid residues responsible for the interaction with Rk, we needed to know the mechanisms of the loss of the S-modulin activity. Therefore, in all of the 15 mutants, we first measured the Ca2+ binding to know the extent of Ca2+ binding and then circular dichroism to detect Ca2+-dependent conformational changes. Fig.6 shows the Ca2+ binding of all of the S-modulin mutants generated. We also measured the binding of S-modulin and two S-modulin mutants, E84M and E120M as controls: wild-type S-modulin binds two Ca2+ at EF-2 and EF-3 (24.Ames J.B. Isima R. Tanaka T. Gordon J.I. Stryer L. Ikura M. Nature. 1997; 389: 198-202Crossref PubMed Scopus (428) Google Scholar) (Fig. 1), while E84M binds one and E120M almost none (21.Matsuda S. Hisatomi O. Ishino T. Kobayashi Y. Tokunaga F. J. Boil. Chem. 1998; 273: 20223-20227Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (21) Google Scholar). The results showed that most of the mutants bind an equal amount of Ca2+ as wild-type S-modulin, but that two mutants (Y108A and R150A) bind less. The binding efficiencies of Y108A and R150A are ∼50 and ∼60% relative to that of wild-type S-modulin, respectively, and are almost the same as that of E84M. These results indicate that Y108A and R150A bind only one Ca2+. To detect Ca2+-dependent conformational changes, we measured CD spectra of S-modulin or its mutants at a low (<1 nm) and a high (200 μm) Ca2+concentration. As shown in Fig.7 A, on Ca2+binding, wild-type S-modulin (wt) increased the negative CD signal at 220–224 nm and decreased the signal at 206–212 nm in agreement with previous reports (22.Duronio R.J. Jackson-Machelski E. Heuckeroth R.O. Olins P.O. Devine C.S. Yonemoto W. Slice L.W. Taylor S.S. Gordon J.I. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1990; 87: 1506-1510Crossref PubMed Scopus (200) Google Scholar, 29.Johnson Jr., W.C. Palczewski K. Gorczyca W.A. Riazance-Lawrence J.H. Witkowska D. Polans A.S. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1997; 1342: 164-174Crossref PubMed Scopus (25) Google Scholar). The increase in the negative signal was approximately 10%. In some of the mutants, the CD spectral change was almost the same as that of the wild-type (Fig. 7 B), but in some of them, the change was very small (Fig. 7 C). Fig. 7 D summarizes the Ca2+-induced CD spectral changes at 220–224 nm in all of the mutants generated. In the 15 mutants, six of them (F22A, E26A, W30A, F55A, T92A, and I154A; indicated by asterisks) showed similar CD spectral changes to that of wild-type S-modulin, which suggested that normal Ca2+-dependent conformational changes took place in these mutants. The other mutants showed decreased spectral changes, although the degree of the decrease differed greatly among the mutants. In all of the mutants, the CD spectrum of the Ca2+-free form resembled that of the Ca2+-free form of the wild-type. Fig.8 compares the results of measurements of the Ca2+ binding (Fig. 6), rhodopsin phosphorylation (Fig.5), and the CD spectral changes (Fig. 7). In this figure, the 15 mutants generated can be classified into three groups. The mutants classified in group A (Y108A and R150A) showed only one Ca2+ binding (Fig. 8, left panel) and they lost the S-modulin activity (Fig. 8, middle panel). The mutants in group B (I154A, W30A, K96A, I181A, L89A, and L16A) bound two Ca2+ and inhibited rhodopsin phosphorylation at a high Ca2+ concentration as wild-type S-modulin did. The members in group C (F55A, E26A, F56A, F22A, K100A, T20A, and T92A) bound two Ca2+ and partially lost the S-modulin activity. In the following, based on the results shown in Fig. 8, we will try to analyze the mechanism of the effect of each mutation to identify the amino acid residues responsible for the interaction with Rk. One point to be mentioned here is that in the present study we did not attempt to discriminate between the binding site and the inhibition (functional) site of the Ca2+-bound form of S-modulin to Rk. In the following, we use the term of “interaction site” which includes both the binding and the inhibition site. The members in group A bind only one Ca2+. In a previous study by Matsuda et al. (21.Matsuda S. Hisatomi O. Ishino T. Kobayashi Y. Tokunaga F. J. Boil. Chem. 1998; 273: 20223-20227Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (21) Google Scholar), they showed that the Ca2+ binding to EF-3 induces the second Ca2+binding to EF-2 and this second Ca2+ binding is essential in eliciting the S-modulin activity. Therefore, the loss of the S-modulin activity in this group would be due to the inability of the second Ca2+ binding. In other words, Tyr108 and Arg150 mutants bind one Ca2+ but probably cannot undergo conformational changes after the first Ca2+binding so that the interaction site of S-modulin to Rk is not formed properly. In Y108A, the CD spectral change at 220–224 nm was very small (Fig. 8, right panel), which indicates that the overall structural change of this mutant is very small even though one Ca2+ binds. In R150A, it was more than 60% of the wild-type, which suggests that the conformational change of this mutant takes place on one Ca2+ binding but yet is not enough to induce the second Ca2+ binding. In group B, the S-modulin activity was not affected appreciably by the mutations, which suggested that these mutations do not affect the interaction between the Ca2+-bound form of S-modulin and Rk. Therefore, although the amino acid residues Leu16, Trp30, Leu89, Lys96, Ile154, and Ile181 are conserved among S-modulin family proteins, these do not seem to be essential in the interaction. However, caution must be taken: alanine may have substituted functionally. In the cases of I154A, W30A, and K96A, the S-modulin activity was enhanced comparing with that of wild-type S-modulin. To elucidate the mechanism of this, further studies are needed. Even though the S-modulin activity was similar as that of the wild-type in group B mutants, the conformational (CD spectral) change induced by two Ca2+ binding varied depending on the mutation. In I154A and W30A, the change was almost the same as that of the wild-type, but in L16A, the change was small. In group C mutants, the S-modulin activity was lost and therefore the amino acid residues in this group are the candidates as the essential amino acid residues responsible for the interaction between the Ca2+-bound form of S-modulin and Rk. When one concludes that a certain amino acid residue is responsible for the interaction, there must be certain criteria to be fulfilled. The simplest case is that such a mutant should: 1) bind two Ca2+; 2) lose the S-modulin activity; and 3) change the conformation in a Ca2+-dependent manner to a similar extent as the wild-type. All of the members in group C fulfill criterion 1 and 2. Even though the CD spectrum gives structural information of whole molecule but not local (that is, the interaction site), four of the mutants in this group, F55A, E26A, F22A, and T92A, showed similar CD spectrum changes as S-modulin and seem to fulfill criterion 3. Therefore, we conclude that these four residues are the “interaction” sites with Rk. One line of the supportive evidence for this is that these four mutants bound to ROS membranes at a high Ca2+ concentration (100 μm) as efficiently as wild-type S-modulin (data not shown). Thus, the loss of the S-modulin activity in these four mutants are not caused by the loss of the Ca2+-dependent binding ability to ROS membranes. The other three in this group (F56A, K100A, and T20A) showed small CD spectrum changes (Fig. 8, right panel). It is not certain at present whether the losses of the S-modulin activity in these three are due to mutations of responsible residues or incomplete conformational changes derived from the mutation. For this reason, we tentatively conclude that these three residues are “possible” interaction sites. Fig. 9 shows the localization of the mutated amino acid residues in the three-dimensional structure of the Ca2+-free form (A) and the Ca2+-bound form (B) of bovine S-modulin. The interaction (red) and the possible (purple) sites are present in a closed pocket in the Ca2+-free form of S-modulin (A), but they appear on the surface around the edge of a groove in the Ca2+-bound form (B). It is interesting that the possible interaction sites are situated near the interaction sites in the Ca2+-bound form. Even though the area around this groove has been speculated as the interaction site to target proteins (24.Ames J.B. Isima R. Tanaka T. Gordon J.I. Stryer L. Ikura M. Nature. 1997; 389: 198-202Crossref PubMed Scopus (428) Google Scholar, 30.Vijay-Kumar S. Kumar V.D. Nature Struct. Biol. 1999; 6: 80-88Crossref PubMed Scopus (103) Google Scholar), all of the conserved amino acid residues in this region do not always seem to be essential in the interaction. For example, substitution of Trp30, Leu89, or Lys96 (green in Fig.9 B) with alanine did not bring about the loss of the S-modulin activity. However, since alanine may possibly substitute the mutated amino acid residue functionally, we need future study for a complete understanding of the interaction sites. Since the interaction and the possible interaction sites are composed of mainly hydrophobic amino acid residues, it is possible that the interaction site of rhodopsin kinase also has hydrophobic residues. In the present study, all of the effective amino acid residues were localized either in or near the peptides 2, 5, and 6 (Fig. 9). In the study of S-modulin partial peptides, however, peptide 9 inhibited rhodopsin phosphorylation (Fig. 2), but yet we could not identify the effective residues in this peptide. One possibility is that we did not properly select the amino acid residues to be mutated in peptide 9. However, it is also possible that the effect of peptide 9 is not specific. Peptide 9 is very hydrophobic and the inhibition of rhodopsin phosphorylation by this peptide was irreversible (data not shown), which suggested that peptide 9 irreversibly denatured Rk to reduce rhodopsin phosphorylation. GCAP1 is an activator of photoreceptor guanylate cyclase. It activates the cyclase at low Ca2+concentrations but inhibits it at high Ca2+ concentrations (31.Dizhoor A.M. Hurley J.B. J. Biol. Chem. 1996; 271: 19346-19350Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (96) Google Scholar, 32.Dizhoor A.M. Boikov S.G. Olshevskaya E.V. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 17311-17314Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (142) Google Scholar). Recent findings showed that a mutation at Y99C in GCAP1 induces a constitutive activation of guanylate cyclase (32.Dizhoor A.M. Boikov S.G. Olshevskaya E.V. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 17311-17314Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (142) Google Scholar). Clinically, this mutation causes autosomal dominant cone dystrophy in a British family (33.Payne A.M. Downes S.M. Bessant D.A.R. Taylor R. Holder G.E. Warren M.J. Bird A.C. Bhattacharya S.S. Hum. Mol. Genet. 1998; 7: 273-277Crossref PubMed Scopus (200) Google Scholar). Although GCAPs do not have the S-modulin activity and most of the interaction and possible sites detected in the present study are not conserved in GCAPs, their amino acid sequences show some homology to S-modulin. It is therefore expected that some of the three-dimensional structure of GCAP1 is similar as that of S-modulin. Interestingly, Tyr99 in GCAP1 corresponds to Tyr108 in S-modulin. Since the Y108A mutant of S-modulin probably cannot bind the second Ca2+ necessary for the conformational change (Fig. 6), Tyr99 mutant in GCAP1 may also bind only one Ca2+. It is therefore possible that the Tyr99 mutant of GCAP1 stays at the Ca2+-free form to activate the cyclase constitutively. After the finding of S-modulin and its bovine homologue, recoverin, many S-modulin-like proteins have been reported. However, in most of the cases, their functions and functional mechanisms are not known. In the present study, we identified the interaction sites of S-modulin. As indicated in the text, most S-modulin family proteins have the S-modulin activity, and therefore, the present finding on the interaction site will provide a general structural mechanism of the action of S-modulin family proteins. We thank Prof. Tokunaga for providing the expression vectors of wild-type S-modulin and mutant proteins (E84M and E120M).

A series of chimeric human Mu class glutathioneS-transferases were designed to determine mechanisms by which they activate enzyme-bound glutathione (GSH) for reaction with electrophilic substrates. In view of evidence that the His107 residue of hGSTM1a-1a is important for catalysis (Patskovsky, Y. V., Patskovska, L. N., and Listowsky, I. (1999) Biochemistry 38, 1193–1202), the cognate Arg107 residue of the hGSTM2 subunit was replaced (R107N or R107H) and arginine residues were also incorporated into position 107 of hGSTM1 (H107R) and hGSTM4 (S107R) subunits. The major distinguishing kinetic properties invariably associated with enzymes containing an Arg107 residue include an inverse dependence ofk cat on viscosity and lowerK mGSH values relative to enzymes with other residues at that position. Moreover, affinities for GSH thiolate anion binding are greater for enzymes containing Arg107, with K d values of 20–50 μm that are consistent with theK mGSH values (10–25 μm) obtained by steady-state kinetic analyses. Both thermodynamic and kinetic and data indicate that the Arg107residue is specifically involved in enhancing the binding affinity of GSH thiolate anion relative to that of the protonated form. These enzymes therefore, can be more effective at lower GSH concentrations. Combined mutations indicate that both Arg107 and Tyr6 residues are required for thiolate anion formation and stabilization. The three-dimensional structure of ligand-free hGSTM2-2 determined by x-ray crystallography suggests that Arg107maintains an electrostatic interaction with the Asp161 side chain (3 Å apart), but is distant from the GSH-binding site. However, an alternative energetically favorable model places the guanidino group 4 Å from the sulfur atom of bound GSH. It is suggested therefore, that in solution, motion of the positively charged arginine into the catalytic pocket could provide a counter ion to promote ionization of the sulfhydryl group of GSH, thereby accounting for the observed greater affinity of enzymes containing Arg107 for binding of thiolate anion. Biol. Chem. 1974; 249: 7130-7139Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar), and CDNBA substrates, were determined by steady-state kinetic analyses. The concentration of GSH and the second substrate were varied independently in the ranges of 0.002–5.0 mm and 0.005–2.5 mm, respectively, in 0.1 m sodium phosphate (or 0.1 m sodium acetate, or 25 mm Tris-HCl, 0.1 m NaCl) buffers in the pH range between 4.0 and 9.0. The apparent kinetic constants,k cat, KmS, and KmGSH for each enzyme were calculated from experimental data obtained from double reciprocal plots of initial velocities versus substrate concentrations using a Milton Roy Co. (Rochester, NY) software program package. The enzyme concentrations were determined spectrophotometrically (at 280 nm) or by use of a Bio-Rad Bradford protein assay solution according to the manufacturer's instructions (Bio-Rad). The values of kcatS for each enzyme and for each substrate were finally recalculated on a per-subunit basis. All measurements were made in triplicate in buffers equilibrated at constant temperature. Assuming that values of dissociation constants for all substrates are equal to their Michaelis constants, the apparent kinetic constants determined for all enzymes tested were consistent with a random sequential or a random equilibrium bisubstrate mechanism of catalysis. The limiting values of rate constants were determined from plots of log k cat versus pH. Graminski G.F. Armstrong R.N. Biochemistry. 1988; 27: 647-654Crossref PubMed Scopus (117) Google Scholar). The appropriate amount of GSH was added to a buffered solution that contained the indicated GST at a fixed concentration of 20 μm (calculated per monomer). Aliquots of GSH were added to final concentrations of 1 to 1000 μm, and solutions of the same concentrations of GSH were used as blanks. A molar extinction coefficient of 4 × 103m−1 cm−1 was used for calculation of molar ratios of protein-bound GSH thiolate anion (see Fig. 2, legend).Solution of Ligand-free hGSTM2-2 Crystal Structure and Modeling ToolsDetails of hGSTM2-2 purification, crystallization, and x-ray data collection were summarized in a previous report (29.Patskovska L. Federov A.A. Patskovsky Y.V. Almo S.C. Listowsky I. Acta Crystallogr. D. 1997; 54: 458-460Crossref Scopus (9) Google Scholar). The crystal structure of a ligand-free enzyme was determined by molecular replacement methods using X-PLOR (version 3.851 (37.Brunger A.T. XPLOR: A System for X-ray Crystallography and NMR, Version 3.1. Yale University Press, New Haven, CT1992Google Scholar) and TOM software (38.Cambillau C. Horjales E. J. Mol. Graph. 1987; 5: 174-177Crossref Scopus (155) Google Scholar), and the hGSTM2-2(W214F) crystal structure was used as a starting model (PDB accession number 1HNA (39.Raghunathan S. Chandross J. Kretsinger R.H. Alliston T.J. Penington C.J. Rule G.S. J. Mol. Biol. 1994; 238: 815-832Crossref PubMed Scopus (115) Google Scholar)). Experimental details of the structure solution were submitted into the Brookhaven protein data base (PDB accession number 2GTU). The progress of refinement was monitored using cross-validation methods. The P1 21 1 monoclinic crystal form of hGSTM2-2 contained two protein monomers or a whole dimer per asymmetric unit. The overall RMSD between backbone atoms of two monomers was about 0.14 Å. Thus, the two monomers are virtually identical. The crystallographic R-factor for 11,894 reflections between 10.0 and 2.55 Å with F>2ςF is 0.20 (R-free is 0.26) with root mean square deviations in bond lengths and angles of 0.011 Å and 1.4°, respectively. All models were designed using an INSIGHTII program package (Biosym Inc.) and SETOR software.The models of the GSH-filled hGSTM2-2 with different configurations of the Arg107 side chain were constructed on the basis of the alignment of three-dimensional structures of hGSTM2-2(W214F) with bound GSH (39.Raghunathan S. Chandross J. Kretsinger R.H. Alliston T.J. Penington C.J. Rule G.S. J. Mol. Biol. 1994; 238: 815-832Crossref PubMed Scopus (115) Google Scholar) and unliganded hGSTM2-2 described in this report. Therefore, the starting models for refinement procedures had coordinates of ligand-free hGSTM2-2 and coordinates of GSH fitted in the G-site of the enzyme. The relative coordinates and stereochemical parameters for GSH atoms were taken from the PDB entry 1HNA. This analysis was feasible because atomic coordinates determined for amino acid residues (including side chains, see below) involved in the maintenance of G-site structures for liganded and ligand-free enzymes are practically identical. RMSD between backbone atoms of G-site residues of these two crystal forms was about 0.2 Å, a figure lower than the estimated coordinate error of 0.25 Å determined for hGSTM2-2. On the basis of the initial model, several secondary models were generated with only the atomic coordinates of Arg107 side chain different between them (potentially different rotamers). These models were refined using a fast cooling protocol (time step = 0.2 fs, temperature range 1500–300° K); these were then used for an additional positional refinement employing structure factors determined for hGSTM2-2 and a resolution range of 3.0–10.0 Å. These energy minimization procedures allowed an improved geometry of side chain atoms and for maintenance of optimal distances. From the starting potential models, only two structures selectively met all necessary criteria mentioned above. Further details of the structure solution and modeling are discussed below.DISCUSSIONThe two major steps of GST catalysis, namely GSH thiolate anion formation and the conjugation reaction with the electrophilic substrate, should be considered independently to interpret the results in this report. The conversion of enzyme-bound GSH to its thiolate anion is not affected by, nor does it require, the presence of the second substrate. The kinetic parameter that primarily reflects the activation of enzyme bound GSH to thiolate is the KmGSH value. The reaction of GSH with the second substrate is reflected by k catand KmS values. Accordingly, there are a number of distinctive properties that are invariably associated with the presence of an Arg107 residue for natural or mutant human Mu class GSTs. These include the lower KmGSH values relative to those for enzymes containing other residues at position 107 (Tables I and IIand Fig. 1, C and F) and lower apparentK d values for GSH thiolate anion formation when that occurs (Fig. 2B). The KmGSHvalues depend on the enzyme variant and not on the second substrate (Tables I and II). These forms of the enzyme thus are more effective at lower GSH levels that may occur under conditions of oxidative stress. In that context it is noteworthy that brain and testis have among the highest tissue levels of hGSTM2 subunits (28.Rowe J.D. Patskovsky Y. Patskovska L.N. Novikova E. Listowsky I. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 9593-9601Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (57) Google Scholar). In addition, turnover numbers for all Arg107-containing enzymes are sensitive to solvent viscosity whereas replacement of this residue of hGSTM2-2 with histidine or asparagine eliminates the viscosity dependence (TableI).On the basis of crystallographic and biochemical data, the hydroxyl group of Tyr6 which is near the active site of Mu class GSTs, has been considered to be a crucial functional group for catalysis by electrophilic stabilization of the thiolate anion of enzyme-bound GSH (22.Armstrong R.N. Chem. Res. Toxicol. 1997; 10: 2-18Crossref PubMed Scopus (954) Google Scholar). Studies on rat GSTs with fluorotyrosyl residues to increase the acidity of the phenolic hydroxyl groups (rGSTM1-1) (42.Parsons J.F. Armstrong R.N. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 1996; 118: 2295-2296Crossref Scopus (35) Google Scholar) and hGSTA1-1 (43.Thorson J.S. Shin I. Chapman E. Stenberg G. Mannervik B. Schultz P.G. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 1998; 20: 451-452Crossref Scopus (25) Google Scholar), reinforce the view that the hydroxyl groups of active-site tyrosine residues of the natural enzymes function by stabilizing thiolate. It is significant, however, that thiolate anion had never been detected in crystal structures of GSTs complexed with GSH (19.Liu S. Zhang P. Ji X. Johnson W.W. Gilliland G.L. Armstrong R.N. J. Biol. Chem. 1992; 267: 4296-4299Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 20.Ji X. Armstrong R.N. Gilliland G.L. Biochemistry. 1993; 32: 12949-12954Crossref PubMed Scopus (89) Google Scholar, 21.Dietze E.C. Ibarra C. Dabrowski M.J. Bird A. Atkins W.M. Biochemistry. 1996; 35: 11938-11944Crossref PubMed Scopus (28) Google Scholar, 22.Armstrong R.N. Chem. Res. Toxicol. 1997; 10: 2-18Crossref PubMed Scopus (954) Google Scholar, 39.Raghunathan S. Chandross J. Kretsinger R.H. Alliston T.J. Penington C.J. Rule G.S. J. Mol. Biol. 1994; 238: 815-832Crossref PubMed Scopus (115) Google Scholar). The data presented in this report suggest that Tyr6 functions together with Arg107 in GST catalysis in at least two different ways. The positive charge of the arginine could promote the ionization of the sulfhydryl group of GSH. The hydroxyl group of Tyr6 indeed could then participate in the stabilization of the GSH thiolate anion. Evidently, however, Tyr6 alone does not effectively stabilize thiolate; the presence of Arg107 or His107 side chains near the active site pocket are also required (Fig. 2). An alternative mechanism for the Tyr6 side chain involvement in catalysis may be deduced from comparison of kinetic constants of wild-type and certain mutant enzymes. In this respect, the most notable results are that an R107N mutant of hGSTM2-2 does not lower the apparent pK a for GSH thiolate anion (Fig.2 B), yet the kinetic pK a with CDNB as substrate is much lower than the pK a for thiolate formation. The apparent inconsistency between the pK a measured by kinetics (pK a of about 6.0, Fig. 1, A, B, and C) and the pK a of thiolate formation of the enzyme bound GSH (≥8.0, Fig. 2 A) suggest that in that case, above a certain pH (the apparent enzymatic pK a, Fig. 1,A and B) the rate of the chemical step of the reaction between GSH thiolate and the electrophilic substrate is no longer rate-limiting. Since the rate of proton transfer from GSH is very fast (>108 s−1), and based on pre-steady state rapid kinetics for all GST variants product release is not rate-limiting, it is likely that binding and productive reorientation of the second substrate for reaction with the GSH nucleophile (transition-state formation) is rate-limiting for catalysis. With CDNBA as substrate, however, the R107N mutant has a kinetic pK a (8.2) close to that of free GSH in solution, so the rate-limiting step for that substrate is probably the conversion of enzyme substrate complex into product. The Y6F mutant has a very low catalytic efficiency with the CDNB second substrate, and the apparent KmCDNB value is increased compared with that of the wild-type enzyme (Table I). A primary function of Tyr6, therefore, could be the binding and orientation of the second substrate as well as for transition state stabilization.Substitutions of the Arg107 residue by His or Asn, causes a decrease ofk cat/ KmGSHand an increase of KmGSH values (see Tables I and II and Fig. 1, C and F). Both KmGSH values, and apparentK d values calculated for thiolate anion formation (see Fig. 2 B) are contingent upon the nature of the side chain of residue 107. Evidently, residue 107 can participate in catalysis by being involved (or not) in thiolate anion stabilization.Binding of GSH and thiolate anion formation at equilibrium may be viewed in terms of the basic thermodynamic cycle shown in Scheme 1, E+GSH ⇌ K1 E+GS(−)+H+ K3⥯⥮K2E·GSH (I)⇌K4 E·GS(−) (II)+H+ SCHEME 1The estimated three log unit pK a difference between that of free GSH in solution (K 1 of approximately 10−9m) and of GSH bound to the GST (K 4 of near 10−6m) is observed for hGSTM2-2 and other Arg107-containing variants (see Fig. 2 A). The overall equilibrium constant for enzyme-GSH thiolate anion formation (structure II, Scheme 1) is 2–5 × 104m−1 from the data in Fig. 2 B. Enzyme-bound GSH thiolate may form by either pathway shown in Scheme 1; therefore K 1 ×K 2 or K 3 ×K 4 should equal 2–5 104m−1 for the Arg107 containing enzymes (Fig. 2 B). That value is also reflected by the respective KmGSH values for these forms of the enzyme (Tables I and II). The apparent equilibrium constant for GSH thiolate anion binding (K 2 of Scheme 1) is therefore greater than that for binding of the protonated GSH (K 3 of Scheme 1). These pathway-independent relationships suggest that after a protonated GSH binds to the enzyme its affinity increases as a consequence of thiolate anion formation and the involvement of the positively charged arginine.Replacement of Arg107 by asparagine in hGSTM2-2 apparently shifts the equilibrium of the enzyme bound GSH toward that of the protonated form (Fig. 2 A). In fact the pK a of the enzyme-bound GSH (K 4) is probably no more than one log unit lower than that of free GSH in solution (K 1). Indeed in that case, the KmGSH values are nearly 50-fold greater than those of the Arg107variants (Tables I and II); however, as discussed above, neither limiting values of turnover numbers nor KmCDNB values are affected. For the R107H substitutions (natural hGSTM1a-1a and chimera), a different mechanism involving a proton transfer reactions on the protein is operative (27.Patskovsky Y.V. Patskovska L.N. Listowsky I. Biochemistry. 1999; 38: 1193-1202Crossref PubMed Scopus (28) Google Scholar). The hGSTM2-2 Y6F mutant has a KmGSH value very similar to that of wild-type enzyme, and apparently significant amounts of GSH thiolate anion do not form as a consequence of binding at pH 7.0 (Fig.2 A). The affinity for the protonated GSH relative to thiolate thus increases with a Y6F substitution, and accounts for the 10,000-fold lower catalytic efficiency.Studies on other forms of the enzyme indicated that a human Alpha class GST h

The utrophin gene codes for a large cytoskeletal protein closely related to dystrophin. Its transcription is driven by a TATA-less promoter. Here we analyzed 40 kilobases of the 5' end region of the utrophin gene searching for new utrophin regulatory elements in muscle cells. By transient transfection of utrophin genomic fragments in front of a reporter gene, we identified a new enhancer that maps downstream of the transcription start site within the second intron and co-localizes with a DNase I-hypersensitive site. By deletion analysis it was mapped to a sequence of 128 base pairs that retains the whole activity. Linker scanning mutagenesis showed that most of the enhancer sequence is essential for its transcriptional activity. Binding analysis with nuclear cell extracts demonstrated that the enhancer regulatory elements, identified by mutagenesis, are protected from DNase I digestion. Because utrophin can functionally substitute dystrophin, the identification and characterization of new regulatory elements provide new targets for possible therapies of Duchenne muscular dystrophy aiming at the up-regulation of the utrophin expression in muscle cells.

The nitrogenase-regulating enzymes dinitrogenase reductase ADP-ribosyltransferase (DRAT) and dinitrogenase reductase-activating glycohydrolase (DRAG), from Rhodospirillum rubrum, were shown to be sensitive to the redox status of the [Fe4S4]1+/2+ cluster of nitrogenase Fe protein from R. rubrum or Azotobacter vinelandii. DRAG had <2% activity with oxidized R. rubrum Fe protein relative to activity with reduced Fe protein. The activity of DRAG with oxygen-denatured Fe protein or a low molecular weight substrate,N α-dansyl-N ω-(1,N6-etheno-ADP-ribosyl)-arginine methyl ester, was independent of redox potential. The redox midpoint potential of DRAG activation of Fe protein was −430 mVversus standard hydrogen electrode, coinciding with the midpoint potential of the [Fe4S4] cluster from R. rubrum Fe protein. DRAT was found to have a specificity opposite that of DRAG, exhibiting low (<20%) activity with 87% reduced R. rubrum Fe protein relative to activity with fully oxidized Fe protein. A mutant of R. rubrum in which the rate of oxidation of Fe protein was substantially decreased had a markedly slower rate of ADP-ribosylation in vivo in response to 10 mm NH4Cl or darkness stimulus. It is concluded that the redox state of Fe protein plays a significant role in regulation of the activities of DRAT and DRAG in vivo.
